title: 104_hr4289
content:
The "Fair Trade Opportunities Act" aims to address trade issues by enabling the President to negotiate better trade benefits for the United States, sanction non-market economy countries, and simplify trade laws. It also includes the repeal of the Jackson-Vanik Act. SEC. 3. REPEAL OF JACKSON-VANIK. The Trade Act of 1974 is repealed, and amendments are made to the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States. Effective on the 15th day after enactment, these changes apply to articles entered or withdrawn from warehouse for consumption. SEC. 4. OUTSTANDING TRADE AGREEMENTS. SEC. 4. OUTSTANDING TRADE AGREEMENTS. Any trade agreement entered into by the United States under title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 remains in effect until expiration, termination, or suspension. Nothing in this Act affects agreements made under different provisions. SEC. 5. OTHER AUTHORITIES NOT AFFECTED. This Act does not impact the authority of the United States Trade Representative or the President to take action under section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974, nor does it affect the President's authority to increase duties on articles from other countries or impose restrictions on imports from other countries under various provisions of law. The President must determine if non-WTO members are providing adequate trade benefits to the US. If not, a tariff increase may be imposed on their products. The President can terminate a tariff increase on a country if it becomes a WTO member or provides adequate trade benefits to the United States. If a country is not a WTO member and lacks a commercial agreement meeting certain requirements, a rate of duty will apply. Under section 405 of the Trade Act of 1974, the column 2 rate of duty under the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States applies to products of a country that is not a WTO member or lacks a commercial agreement meeting specific requirements. The term "WTO member" refers to a state or separate customs territory to which the United States applies the WTO Agreement. The "WTO Agreement" refers to the Agreement Establishing the World Trade Organization signed on April 15, 1994. SEC. 7. OTHER AUTHORITY TO INCREASE TARIFFS.

President authorized to increase duty rate on products from non-market economy countries not in WTO to 1994 levels if they restrict emigration rights.

SEC. 8. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to remove certain resolutions and introduce changes in the introduction and referral process. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to remove resolutions and make changes to the introduction and referral process. Amendments include striking paragraphs and references to resolutions in various subsections. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to remove resolutions and make changes to the introduction and referral process. This includes repealing Section 153 and amending Section 154 by removing references to certain resolutions. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to modify Section 330(d) of the Tariff Act of 1930, specifically regarding the determination of increased imports causing serious injury. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to modify Section 330(d) of the Tariff Act of 1930, specifically regarding the determination of increased imports causing serious injury. Additionally, amendments are made to various sections of other trade acts, such as the Trade Agreements Act of 1979 and the Support for East European Democracy (SEED) Act of 1989. These amendments involve changes to trade status provisions for East European countries.
